Formatting of this note is different from the original.
A copy of these instructions will be made available to your primary care doctor or nurse practitioner: JOEL K LYM MD
You were treated in the hospital for alcohol withdrawal.
Non-Operative Procedures: None
You can call the appointment / advice line at 1-866-454-8855, if you experience any of the following symptoms:
Temperature of 101 degrees F or above.
Pain unrelieved by medication.
Persistent nausea, vomiting and/or inability to eat.
Increase in fatigue, confusion or dizziness.
Diarrhea that is bloody or occurs more than 5-6 times a day or persists for more than 3-4 days.
You can also send your doctor a non-urgent message at www.kp.org under My Message Center. Response may take up to 2 business days.
Call 911 for emergencies.
FOLLOW UP APPOINTMENTS
You have an appointment with your regular doctor, JOEL K LYM MD, in 5 - 7 days.
Telephone and Video Visit Appointments (DONE REMOTELY in your place)

TOPICS TO DISCUSS WITH MY DOCTOR

-stop alcohol

DIET

ADDICTION MEDICINE CONSULT AND LIAISON SERVICE
CONSULT & SUPPORTIVE SERVICES NOTE:
Psychologist (non-MD)
This is a telephone consult for pt to ensure pt has adequate resources and care plan in preparation for d/c, ADDM team serving pt remotely from SLN.
IMPRESSION: Manav Agarwal is a 33 Y male admitted for alcohol withdrawal.
Addiction Medicine Psychologist met with patient in order to:
- gather additional relevant clinical information
- provide psycho-education on the consequences of pt's Substance Use
- provide psycho-education on treatment options
- assist patient in clarifying their change goals
- enhance patient's motivation for treatment
Additional Relevant History: Pt has prior hospitalizations for ETOH and benzo w/d.
MENTAL STATUS EXAMINATION
Appearance: could not asses
Behavior: normal

Speech: normal

Affect: mood congruent

Suicidal Ideation: denied

Additional Diagnostic Impressions: Pt motivated for treatment, needs help navigating county system.
Treatment Goals:
Motivation/Stage of Change:Preparation/Determination: Committed and planning to make change in the near future but is still actively deciding how to change.
Patient's Goals:Stop completely/continued abstinence- alcohol
Benefits/Coverage: Alameda Alliance
Referral to: provided instruction on how to access Alameda Alliance SUD services. Recommended AA online and provided links to meetings with online access for COVID time.
Coordination of Care actions planned/taken: offered tw contact number for f/u support, encouraged pt to utilize PSYCH coverage if needed concurrent with SUD tx, explained country service delivery model and benefits of getting on waitlist for options of levels of care.
This patient does not have current outpatient Addiction Medicine provider(s), and this note is not routed to them via HC message.
This note is routed to the OP Addiction Medicine Clinic via e-consult for review on the next non-holiday, non-weekend, working day, to arrange for follow up appointment.
If not, why: no coverage.
Potential risks, adverse reactions, and benefits were discussed with patient as well as alternative treatments. Patient understands and is able and willing to participate in treatment planning.
Thank you for this consult.
Ryan Berman, Psy.D.
Psychologist

item.caption: LOUAI ALI BILAL MD - 05/22/2020 1:29 PM PDT
item.paragraph:
Formatting of this note is different from the original.
PSYCHIATRY INITIAL CONSULTATION
DO NOT COPY FOR EXTERNAL RELEASE WITHOUT A SIGNED AUTHORIZATION TO RELEASE PSYCHIATRIC INFORMATION
1. ID/REFERRING INFORMATION
Manav Agarwal is a 33 Y Indian American male admitted to hospital for palpitations. Ataie, Yalda (M.D.) requested a mental health consultation for anxiety, depression .
2. HISTORY:
History of Current Situation:
Manav Agarwal is a 33 Y male with history of alcohol use disorder, ADHD, GAD, depression admitted due to palpitations. He has been drinking alcohol excessively for the past week or so. Said he experiences panic type anxiety at least twice daily. He takes cymbalta for depression.
He said he has been experiencing stress from school and a relationship breaking.
He denied any current suicidal ideation, intent, or plan.
No psychosis, mania, OCD, PTSD.
Had been sober he claims until about a week ago when he started binging with alcohol.
He is postgrad at Stanford studying data science and lives with his parents.
Energy Level: impaired
Sleep: impaired
Appetite: stable
Case was discussed with requesting physician.
History in chart/electronic record was reviewed.
History was not obtained from Call Center.
Psychiatric History:
Prior diagnoses: alcohol use disorder, ADHD, GAD, depression
Prior suicide or parasuicidal behaviors: suspected of OD in 2/2018 but he denied. Said he was heavily intoxicated and may have taken more temazepam at the time
Prior threats or assault behaviors: None
Outpatient psychiatric treatment: individual therapy and medication management
Inpatient psychiatric hospitalization: Overnight stay at John George Pavilion
Prior psychiatric medications and outcomes: tried few antidepressants remeron, effexor, prozac, zoloft generally they do not help or cause side effects
Taken gabapentin and some benzodiazepines, lorazepam and xanax intermittently

4. RISK ASSESSMENT
Patient has no access to firearms.
Risk of self harm is acutely Low and chronically Low.
Risk of harm to others is acutely Low and chronically Low.
A Tarasoff notification (duty to protect) is not indicated.
5. IMPRESSION:
Specific Findings and Narrative Assessment:
Manav Agarwal is a 33 Y male with alcohol use disorder and anxiety presented with palpitations and alcohol withdrawal. He continues to complain of panic type anxiety and depression but unfortunately he continues to consume large amounts of alcohol
Axis I: Generalized anxiety by history, alcohol use disorder, ADHD, rule out alcohol induced anxiety
6. RECOMMENDATIONS:
1. Continue cymbalta at current dose
2. May discharge with naltrexone 50 mg daily, librium 25 mg tid as needed for severe anxiety ( # 10), gabapentin 400 mg tid as needed for anxiety
3. Advised patient to stop alcohol intake and to not take adderral for the time being. He agreed.
3. Will refer to CHEMICAL DEPENDENCY RECOVERY PROGRAM ( econsult entered)
4. Will route note to outpatient psychiatrist for follow up appointment
Above recommendations and current expectations for for follow-up or disposition were verbally reviewed with the attending physician, Ataie, Yalda (M.D.).
7. DISPOSITION:
The options of inpatient psychiatric hospitalization, partial psychiatric hospitalization, crisis residential services, 23-hour bed, nursing facility placement, and discharge to home were not considered. If inpatient medical hospitalization were not recommended by the attending physician, the most appropriate disposition for this patient right now would be home.
Security was not contacted or asked to remain.
Patient was not placed or kept on 5150 due to danger to self .
A sitter is not recommended at this time.
8. FOLLOW UP:
Indication for consultant to follow-up in the hospital?: No.
Hayward Hospital (9am to 5pm, excluding weekends and holidays):
Call system speed 152 if the attending physician requires an urgent reassessment by mental health. Psychiatry Consult Physician of the day can be contacted at system speed 038 if additional assistance is requested.
Fremont Hospital (9am to 5pm, excluding weekends and holidays):
Call tie line 8-431-3215 to contact the Psychiatry Consult Physician of the day, or if the attending physician requires an urgent reassessment by mental health.
After-Hours Psychiatry Call Center (tie line 8-422-7713) should be contacted if an urgent reassessment is required after hours, holidays, or weekends.
A new appointment in the department of psychiatry is mandatory within a week if the patient is sent directly home from the emergency department after a suicide attempt.
The patient has not had a recent suicide attempt, and therefore advising the Psychiatry clinic to arrange urgent outpatient follow-up in less than one week is not indicated.
This note is not routed to the Fremont Psychiatry Immediate Service Team pool (P FRE PSYCH TRIAGE) or Union City Psychiatry Triage pool (P UNC PSYCH TRIAGE) for review on the next non-holiday, non-weekend, working day, to arrange for follow up .
This patient does have current outpatient mental health provider(s), and this note is routed to them.
A voicemail is not indicated for the mental health consultant working the next on-call shift (510-675-4954) and a message was not left.
The Psychiatric Call Center was not contacted and informed of the patient's status. (Weekday: 8-422-1103; After-hours: 8-422-7713)
9. MEDICAL CLEARANCE:
The telephone number of the Kaiser Psychiatric Call Center Admissions Coordinator is 8-422-1103 (8-422-7713 on weekends and holidays and after 5pm on weekdays)
If patient is evaluated in the ED, Urgent Care, or Medical Hospital, and is to be transferred to a psychiatric facility, the attending physician must document if the patient is or is not medically cleared for discharge or transfer to psychiatric facility.
